IF you go on the website there are videos on the site and because I am a ow=
ner even my tech friends who are not=C2=A0impressed by anything when seeing=
 this was Wowed! but hey its just my opinion. You can get it or not. I'm ha=
ppy I have it..and you right if you don't do investigation (which I don't m=
uch, I have a group to do that for me) but I do other things. If your not g=
oing to use it, the money spent wouldn't make sense,for me it is a investme=
nt.

--- On Thu, 12/16/10, Country <countrybumpkin1956@...> wrote:


=
From: Country <countrybumpkin1956@...>
Subject: [EVP-ITC] Re: Full Sp=
ectrum Cameras (Moditronics)
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thursday, De=
cember 16, 2010, 7:34 PM


=C2=A0 



Hello....
I, too, have a Moditronics =
UV/IR Full Spectrum HD Camcorder and a Moditronics Deep IR Still Camera (ma=
de by SVP). I agree that the camcorder is incorrectly named as it is not fu=
ll spectrum. It is the UV and IR fields I am interested in anyway.

Both ar=
e made from low quality, in my opinion, cameras. But whatever the technolog=
y this company uses in their units is very good, and I have yet to see it d=
uplicated. Their deep IR still camera will not pick up dust orbs, for examp=
le. When you get an orb on the still camera, chances are it is something...=
they are often self illuminating, solid or near solid white, often have a t=
ail. I have also gotten very, very few orbs using this camera as well.

I d=
id buy this same SVP camera but modified by a different equipment supplier =
on the internet. It does show every dust orb there is, the picture quality =
is a bit blurry or fuzzy many times. I was very disappointed.

One thing ab=
out the SVP still camera is if you drop it, even once, you will have a brok=
en SD card slot. I was sold one on Ebay from someone who knew the SD card w=
as broken and never revealed it. Some research showed me what the possible =
reason was...it cannot take a drop. So handle it with care. Their packing s=
lip even says they will not warrant the camera against drops. But you proba=
bly won't find that advertised on their web site though.

I found it intere=
sting and somewhat amusing that Ghost Hunters on tv showed up with this equ=
ipment in their series. However the Moditronics label was ripped off, the g=
lue was still on the camera and there was a zoom in to this portion of one =
of the cameras.

In regards to the spectercams, in this economy and with th=
e infrequency that I investigate, I cannot justify spending what any of the=
 spectercams go for. If I were going out to investigate every week or every=
 other week, then sure I could justify spending more money. But I would be =
nervous without having more reviews from users and especially those that ha=
ve caught something on the Spectercam.

Hope this helps,
CB

In EVP-ITC@yah=
oogroups.com, "draiga1" <mail@...> wrote:
> Thank you so much, Sharon. I wa=
s hoping someone had the moditronics camera too. It sounds like it works gr=
eat for what I want. I appreciate you sharing your results with it.

From m=
y experience with all kinds of cameras, I say it's best to experiment. On o=
ne of my experiments, I went to a purported haunted alley and took 4 differ=
ent shots using 4 different cameras from the same angle, taking the photos =
one after the other within a minute's span. The 4 cameras I used were: 1. M=
oditronics' so-called "Full Spectrum" (which I've dubbed "Duo-Spectrum" bec=
ause it only sees into the near UV and IR spectrums, excluding the visible =
spectrum altogether) and 2. Moditronics "Deep IR" which only sees into the =
IR spectrum, excluding the visible and UV spectrums, 
> > Sharon from SF


=
